name: EU Cloud Sovereignty Framework
description: European Union framework for assessing cloud service sovereignty based on 8 dimensions

guidance.0: No identified risk or concern. Full sovereignty maintained.
guidance.1: Minimal risk, easily mitigated. Minor dependencies that don't affect sovereignty.
guidance.2: Low risk, standard mitigations available. Some foreign dependencies but manageable.
guidance.3: Moderate risk, requires attention. Notable sovereignty concerns that need addressing.
guidance.4: Significant risk, requires action plan. Serious sovereignty gaps affecting data/operations.
guidance.5: Critical risk, may be unacceptable. Fundamental sovereignty issues, consider alternatives.

low.label: Low Risk
low.description: Minimal sovereignty concerns. Provider aligns well with EU interests.
low.recommendation: Suitable for most use cases including sensitive data with standard controls.

moderate.label: Moderate Risk
moderate.description: Some sovereignty concerns that can be addressed with available mitigations.
moderate.recommendation: Acceptable for general use. Review mitigations before handling sensitive data.

elevated.label: Elevated Risk
elevated.description: Notable sovereignty gaps requiring active management and monitoring.
elevated.recommendation: Use with caution. Implement mitigations and have exit strategy ready.

significant.label: Significant Risk
significant.description: Serious sovereignty concerns affecting data control and legal exposure.
significant.recommendation: Avoid for sensitive data. Evaluate alternatives. Requires risk acceptance.

high.label: High Risk
high.description: Critical sovereignty issues. High exposure to foreign jurisdiction and vendor lock-in.
high.recommendation: Not recommended. Seek alternatives or accept significant residual risk.

dimensions.name: Strategic Autonomy
dimensions.description: Assessment of strategic dependency on the cloud service provider, including market dominance, geopolitical alignment, and long-term availability risks

dimensions.name: Legal Jurisdiction
dimensions.description: Exposure to foreign legal frameworks that may compel data access or conflict with EU/national law
considerations: Applicable data access laws (CLOUD Act, FISA, etc.)
Conflict with GDPR and EU law

dimensions.name: Data Sovereignty
dimensions.description: Control over data location, access, encryption, and lifecycle management

dimensions.name: Operational Sovereignty
dimensions.description: Ability to maintain operations independently of the vendor, including self-hosting and operational control

dimensions.name: Supply Chain
dimensions.description: Dependencies and risks in the vendor's supply chain, including subprocessors and infrastructure providers

dimensions.name: Technology Independence
dimensions.description: Degree of vendor lock-in and ability to migrate to alternative solutions

dimensions.name: Security
dimensions.description: Security certifications, practices, and compliance with security standards

dimensions.name: Environmental Sustainability
dimensions.description: Environmental impact, energy efficiency, and sustainability commitments

cloud_act.description: True if vendor country is subject to US CLOUD Act

schrems_ii.description: True if data transfers raise Schrems II concerns

level.description: Calculated from average of dimension scores
